newsitem.title: FRANCE: Euro-court backs British limits on sex abuse cases.
newsitem.headline: Euro-court backs British limits on sex abuse cases.

text.p: The European Court of Human Rights ruled on Tuesday that four young British women had had enough time under British law to seek damages for childhood sexual abuse.
Rejecting a plea by the four women, the Strasbourg-based court upheld British law which gives a person until the age of 24 to start civil proceedings over such abuse.
"The very essence of the applicants' right of access to court was not impaired since they had six years from their 18th birthdays in which to initiate civil proceedings," the court found.
"Limitation periods serve the legitimate aims of ensuring legal certainty and finality," the court ruled.
The case had been brought before the rights court by Leslie Stubbings, now 39, and three other women aged 34 to 38 who were identified solely by their initials.
All four alleged they had been sexually abused as children by a parent, an adoptive parent or a school master, but became aware of the abuse only years later with the help of therapy.
They said they had been unable to sue for damages because too many years had passed before they discovered the abuse.
They argued that the statute of limitations on such cases should only begin running after a victim became aware of the abuse.
The court said sexual abuse was "unquestionably an abhorrent type of wrongdoing, with debilitating effects on its victims".
But it said that even when civil law did not apply, children and other vulnerable individuals were still protected by criminal laws.
